perturbation.original_text: The Trust shall pay all of its operating expenses, including but not limited to fees due the Sponsor under this Agreement, compensation of Trustees not affiliated with the Sponsor, governmental fees, including but not limited to Securities and Exchange Commission fees and state "blue sky" fees; interest charges; taxes and related charges; membership dues of the Trust in the Investment Company Institute and other professional or industry associations; fees and expenses of the Trust's independent auditors and accountants, of legal counsel and any transfer agent, distributor, shareholder servicing agent, recordkeeper, registrar or dividend disbursing agent of the Trust; expenses of distributing, issuing and redeeming shares and servicing shareholder accounts; expenses of preparing, printing and mailing prospectuses and statements of additional information, reports, notices, proxy statements and reports to shareholders and governmental officers and commissions; expenses connected with the execution, recording and settlement of portfolio security transactions; insurance premiums; fees and expenses of the Trust's custodian for all services to the Trust, including safekeeping of funds and securities and maintaining required books and accounts; expenses of calculating the net asset value of shares of the Trust; expenses of shareholder meetings; and expenses relating to the issuance, registration and qualification of shares of any series of the Trust.
perturbation.changed_text: The Trust may pay some of its operating expenses, including fees due the Sponsor under this Agreement, compensation of Trustees not affiliated with the Sponsor, governmental fees, including Securities and Exchange Commission fees and state "blue sky" fees; interest charges; taxes and related charges; membership dues of the Trust in the Investment Company Institute and other professional or industry associations; fees and expenses of the Trust's independent auditors and accountants, legal counsel, transfer agent, distributor, shareholder servicing agent, recordkeeper, registrar, or dividend disbursing agent; expenses of distributing, issuing, and redeeming shares and servicing shareholder accounts; expenses of preparing, printing, and mailing prospectuses and statements of additional information, reports, notices, proxy statements, and reports to shareholders and governmental officers and commissions; expenses connected with the execution, recording, and settlement of portfolio security transactions; insurance premiums; fees and expenses of the Trust's custodian for all services, including safekeeping of funds and securities and maintaining required books and accounts; expenses of calculating the net asset value of shares of the Trust; expenses of shareholder meetings; and expenses relating to the issuance, registration, and qualification of shares of any series of the Trust.
perturbation.explanation: The original text states that 'The Trust shall pay all of its operating expenses.' By changing 'shall' to 'may,' the modified text introduces uncertainty regarding which expenses the Trust is obligated to cover. This contradicts the original mandatory language and makes the allocation of expenses ambiguous.

perturbation.original_text: For the services to be rendered and facilities to be provided by the Sponsor hereunder, the Trust shall pay Domini a fee accrued daily and payable monthly at an annual rate equal to 0.50% of the Trust's average daily net assets for the Trust's then current fiscal year. If Domini serves as the Sponsor for less than the whole of any period specified in this Section 3, the compensation to Domini, as Sponsor, shall be prorated. For purposes of computing the fees payable to the Sponsor hereunder, the value of the Trust's net assets shall be computed in the manner specified in the Trust's then-current prospectus and statement of additional information.
perturbation.changed_text: For the services to be rendered and facilities to be provided by the Sponsor hereunder, the Trust may pay Domini a fee accrued at the end of the year and payable based on a rate to be determined at the discretion of the Trust's Board. If Domini serves as the Sponsor for less than the whole of any period specified in this Section 3, the compensation to Domini, as Sponsor, may be prorated. For purposes of computing the fees payable to the Sponsor hereunder, the value of the Trust's net assets will be subject to review and discretionary adjustment by the Trust.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause establishes a specific and mandatory fee structure (0.50% of average daily net assets, accrued daily, payable monthly). The modified clause changes 'shall' to 'may,' making payment discretionary. It replaces the fixed percentage with a rate 'determined at the discretion of the Trust's Board,' introduces the possibility that proration is not guaranteed, and says that net asset value computation is subject to 'discretionary adjustment,' conflicting with the original text's clear methodology and potentially leading to disputes over the Sponsor's compensation.

perturbation.original_text: This Agreement may be terminated at any time, without the payment of any penalty, with respect to any series or the Trust, by the Board of Trustees of the Trust, or by the Sponsor, in each case on not less than 60 days' written notice to the other party.
perturbation.changed_text: This Agreement may be terminated at any time by mutual agreement of the Board of Trustees of the Trust and the Sponsor. Termination by either party independently is subject to a termination fee, as determined by an independent arbitrator, and requires 120 days' written notice.
perturbation.explanation: The original text clearly states that either party (the Board of Trustees or the Sponsor) can terminate the agreement 'at any time, without the payment of any penalty,' with 60 days' notice. The modified version contradicts this by stating that termination requires 'mutual agreement,' introduces a 'termination fee' if either party terminates independently, and doubles the notice period to 120 days. This introduces considerable uncertainty and risk, as now termination is no longer a straightforward process.
